title: Buoyant force - tension in cable holding balloon

content.question: The weather balloon shown in the figure has a volume of <math alttext="120 cubic meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>120</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>3</mtext></msup></math> and is filled with a gas of density <math alttext="0.19 kilograms per cubic meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>0.19</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mtext>kg/m</mtext><mtext>3</mtext></msup></mstyle></math>. The volume of the balloon material is negligible. The mass of the balloon, not including the gas, is <math alttext="50 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></math>. The balloon is attached to the ground by a cable. The air surrounding the balloon has a density of <math alttext="1.2 kilograms per cubic meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><msup><mtext>kg/m</mtext><mtext>3</mtext></msup></math>. skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
